name: Role-Based Onboarding and Customization
description: This use case facilitates the tailored setup of ALFRED for older adults and their caregivers, allowing personalized configuration of notifications, privacy settings, and interaction modes to suit the distinct needs and preferences of medical staff, informal caregivers, and elder users.
scenario:
Mike Johnson, a registered nurse working long shifts in a busy urban hospital, approached the ALFRED onboarding session with a clear agenda: he needed fast access to critical patient data and zero distractions during work hours. When ALFRED prompted him to configure notification settings, Mike immediately blocked all non-critical alerts, concerned that even a brief interruption could derail his focus on patients. He found the voice assistant’s friendly explanations unnecessary and preferred to navigate the system on his own terms, bypassing tutorials to dive straight into clinical data views. Mike was particularly cautious about any features that might encourage emotional engagement; he explicitly disabled game invitations or social suggestions, seeing them as time-wasters during his demanding shifts.

Meanwhile, Sarah Thompson, an informal caregiver juggling care for several older adults, embraced ALFRED’s flexibility differently. She eagerly accepted all notifications, including those about social activities or light interactions, believing these could help her clients feel less isolated. While Mike rejected automatic logging of interactions, Sarah preferred to manage records manually, wanting full control over what care details were recorded. She saw value in ALFRED’s games and chats as tools to bond with her clients, so she kept those features enabled and even planned to use the system to coordinate fun activities remotely. Sarah’s home environment, filled with family and shared care duties, meant she needed ALFRED to be a constant, attentive presence, always ready to notify her regardless of the hour.

Olivia, the older adult at the center of this setup, met the process with skepticism and guardedness. Technology overwhelmed her, and she was deeply concerned about privacy. She immediately restricted ALFRED from installing any new apps without her explicit permission and limited data sharing to the bare minimum, refusing even her caregivers broad access. Olivia’s interactions with ALFRED were terse; she preferred the voice assistant to keep exchanges strictly formal and minimal, dismissing explanations she found patronizing. She declined invitations for video check-ins, fearing intrusion, and ignored notifications about physical exercises she found too demanding. Her insistence on controlling every aspect of ALFRED’s behavior often clashed with Sarah’s desire for active engagement and Mike’s clinical requirements. This tension made the onboarding a delicate balancing act, with ALFRED navigating between Mike’s need for streamlined, clinical efficiency, Sarah’s inclusive and nurturing approach, and Olivia’s protective, cautious stance toward technology and privacy.
